title: James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography
author: Nasmyth, James
snippet: But to see the skilful manner inwhich these native workmen, drawn from the staff of the Bairds'ordinary foundry workers, performed their duties, was truly surprising.

title: James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography
author: Nasmyth, James
snippet: This, as well as the Corinthian capitals of bronze,was manufactured at the foundry of the Bairds.

title: James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography
author: Nasmyth, James
snippet: The Bairdshave ever been a loyal and gallant family.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: To-day while we were out the Bairds and Rochambeaus called.

title: Eight journeys abroad /
author: Rosengarten, Mary D. Richardson
snippet: I have sent cards to the Bairds and Rochambeaus this evening.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: Erskine is left to the second son of the Bairds," Willie," a nice young fellow, who will make an excellentcountry squire.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: We met one of his daughtersConstance Emmot, at dinner at the Bairds' on the 28th ;and on the 30^ had luncheon at Kensington with Lomeand the Princess, and their account was no better.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: Afterwards I crossed the Green Park and looked inat the Bairds at Eaton Place.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: 3°9 OLD DIARIES [1897nie Macdonald, a sister of my niece-in-law, Lily Cromartiethe next evening I dined with the Bairds, afterwardsgoing with them and some of their guests to see theilluminations in the city; but we were rather what inAmerica is called "previous," for the illuminations werefew and far between; however, the aspect of the streetsand the vast and wonderfully well-behaved crowd whichthronged them was well worth seeing.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: The former were the twoBairds and Elspeth Campbell, and there came to meetthem young Douglas Loch, a tall youth in the Foot Guards(son of Lord Loch), and young Lord Elphinstone.

snippet: From Erskine I went to the Bairds at Newbyth.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: In those bygone days none seemed to understand the vast resources of America, or to believe in her manifest destiny ; but Mr. Whitelaw,  then M. P. for Glasgow, and one of the Bairds, was one who knew the possibilities of that future better than his guests who laughed.

title: Our coaching trip,
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: We travelled most of the day through the ore lands and among the blast furnaces of the Scotch pig-iron kings, the Bairds.

author: Carnegie, Andrew
